Fire and Life Safety                                                                   Environmental Health and Safety                             To support New York University’s teaching, research, and service missions, Environmental and Health and Safety (EHS) assists NYU around the world to meet its responsibility to protect students, employees and the environment and to provide a safe and healthy place of employment and learning. Environmental Health and Safety includes Fire and Life Safety. Melisa Puglisi is Director of Environmental Health and Safety and she can be reached at 212.98.1438 and at melisa.puglisi@nyu.edu    Environmental Health and Safety provides occupational and environmental health and safety services to all faculty, students and staff, including maintaining compliance with federal, state and local laws and regulations related to occupational health and safety, environmental conservation and protection, and laboratory safety. Environmental Health and Safety also provides emergency response, technical support, information and training programs, and environmental health and safety consulting and auditing services.    Fire and Life Safety’s mission is to ensure the safety of the New York University community through the interpretation of fire protection codes and standards and the application of engineering principals. This is accomplished through the review and approval of drawings and technical documents for the construction of new buildings as well as the review and approval of similar documents for alteration/renovation, of any size, in existing buildings. In addition, this unit investigates university facilities to ensure that fie risks are minimized. James Gillespie is the Global Manager of Fire and Life Safety and can be reached at 212.998.1423 and at j.gillespie@nyu.edu                         Contact Us     NYU Environmental Health and Safety  10 Astor Place, 6th Floor  New York, New York 10003  Phone: +1 212-998-1450  Fax: +1 212-995-4775   ehs@nyu.edu     Full list of personnel contact information »              Quick Tips   The following Quick Tips were developed as quick-reference guides to some of our more common policies and procedures. Neuroscience, Brigham Young University  M.S. Environmental Health Science, New York University  Ph.D. Environmental Health Science, New York University   Other Appointments:  Adjunct Fellow, Institute for Policy Integrity, NYU School of Law   Affiliated Faculty, Marron Institute on Cities and the Urban Environment, New York University   Professional Service:  American Thoracic Society (ATS), Environmental and Occupational Health (EOH) Assembly Planning Committee  NYU-NIEHS Community Outreach and Education Core (COEC) Internal Advisory Board  NYU GSAS Department of Environmental Health Science Graduate Steering Committee  NYU-NIEHS Metals Focus Group   Current Projects: - Long-term Air Pollution Exposure and Mortality in the NIH-AARP Cohort - The Interaction of Diet, Air Pollution, and Cardiovascular Disease in NHANES. - The Effect of Peak-Shaving Regulations on the Activity, Toxic Emissions, and Health Impacts of Local Power Plants   Current Courses:  Global Issues in Environmental Health, EHSC-GA 1011  Environmental Health Policy, EHSC-GA 1013   Selected Publications:   Cromar K . and Schwartz J. (2010) Residual Risks–the unseen costs of using dirty oil in New York City Boilers. Institute for Policy Integrity. New York University School of Law: New York, NY. ( http://policyintegrity.org/files/publications/ResidualRisks.pdf )   Cromar K . and Schwartz J. (2010) More residual risks: an update on New York City boilers. Institute for Policy Integrity. New York University School of Law: New York, NY. ( http://policyintegrity.org/files/publications/More_Residual_Risks.pdf )   Peltier R.,  K. Cromar , Y. Ma, Z. Fan, and M. Lippmann. (2011)  Spatial and seasonal distribution of aerosol chemical components in New York City : 2) Road dust and other tracers of traffic-generated air pollution. Journal of Exposure Science and Environmental Epidemiology. 21(5): 484-494.   Cromar K , Ito K, Silverman R, Thurston G. (2011).  "Obesity and Metabolic Syndrome: Risk Factors for Air Pollution Related Asthma Hospital Admission." Abstracts of the 23rd Annual Conference of the International Society of Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE). September 13 - 16, 2011, Barcelona, Spain. Environ Health Perspect. ( http://dx.doi.org/10.1289/ehp.isee2011 )   Cromar, K ., G.D. Thurston, and R. Lall. (2012) Mobile Source Air Toxics Mitigation Measures, Literature Review – Priority MSATs Health Effects. New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) Project C-08-12.   Cromar, K ., L. Perlmutt, and G.D. Thurston. (2012) Mobile Source Air Toxics Mitigation Measures, Identify and Assess MSAT Monitoring Data. New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) Project C-08-12.   Cromar K ., R. Silverman, K. Ito, and G. Thurston. (2012).  "Bronchitis, but not Upper Respiratory Tract Infection, Increases the Risk of Air Pollution Related Asthma Hospital Admission."  Epidemiology. 23(5S): September 2012. (doi: 10.1097/01.ede.0000417343.55467.a9)   Schwartz J.,  K. Cromar , and S. Soloway. (2012) How regulating electricity demand could save lives in New York City. Institute for Policy Integrity. New York University School of Law: New York, NY. ( http://policyintegrity.org/files/publications/Peak_Efficiency_Policy_Brief.pdf )   Holladay S., E. Pienaar, and  K. Cromar . (2012). Health Effects of Peak Shaving Regulations in New York City: A Natural Experiment. Association of Environmental and Resource Economics session at the 87th Annual Conference of the Western Economic Association International.   Perlmutt L., Jin L., and  K. Cromar . (2012). "The Use of CALPUFF Dispersion Model to Investigate PM2.5 Attributable to Residual Oil Power Plants in New York City?"  22nd Annual Meeting of the International Society of Exposure Science conference (ISES).                          Mission   Wagner Environmental Policy and Action (WEPA) is dedicated to raising the environmental awareness of the Wagner Graduate School of Public Service community and contributing to the process of making New York University a more environmentally educated and responsible institution.
